The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). Authors computed a basic reproduction number of 4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), which decreased to 2.08 (95% CI 1.99e2.18) on January 22nd, 2020. Based on these estimates, the pandemics outbreak is expected to significantly decrease within 77 [95% CI 75e80] days from its beginning. Furthermore, authors found that every one-day reduction in the duration of the period from illness/symptom onset to isolation would reduce the peak population size by 72e84% and the cumulative infected cases and deaths both by 68e80%. The study by Majumder and Mandl (Majumder & Mandl, 2020) utilized the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model and led to an estimate of the reproduction number in the range of 2.0e3.1. Finally, Riou and Althaus (Riou & Althaus, 2020), using a stochastic model simulating epidemics trajectories, computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8). Using statistical approaches, namely exponential growth and maximum likelihood techniques, Liu and colleagues (Liu et al., 2020) estimated the value of the reproduction number ranging from 2.90 (95% CI 2.32e3.63) to 2.92 (95% CI 2.28e3.67). author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Controlling and containing the coronavirus outbreak requires a high percentage of transmission to be effectively managed. Research by Imai et al. (2020) and Yu (2020) suggests that a quarantine rate of over 90% of the infectious population is necessary. Kucharski et al. (2020) developed a stochastic SEIR model with a time-varying reproduction number to provide real-time estimates. The model considered transmission as a fluctuating process, with the risk of causing a large outbreak modeled based on a negative binomial distribution. Before travel restrictions were put in place, the median reproduction number ranged from 1.6 to 2.9.The study by Wu and collaborators (Wu et al., 2020), based on nowcasting and forecasting approach, estimated a basic reproductive number of 2.68 (95% credible interval or CrI 2.47e2.86) with 75,815 individuals (95% CrI 37,304e130,330) being infected in Wuhan as of January 25th, 2020. The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). Authors computed a basic reproduction number of 4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), which decreased to
post_context:
(95% CI 1.99e2.18) on January 22nd, 2020.Based on the estimates provided, it is projected that the pandemic outbreak will decrease significantly within approximately 77 days (95% CI 75-80) from its initial onset. The study by Majumder and Mandl (2020) utilized the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model and estimated a reproduction number in the range of 2.0-3.1. Riou and Althaus (2020) computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4-3.8) using a stochastic model. Liu et al. (2020) estimated a reproduction number ranging from 2.90 (95% CI 2.32-3.63) to 2.92 (95% CI 2.28-3.67) using statistical approaches. Zhang and Wang (2020) found that the time of the most recent common ancestor was December 17th, 2019, and that the reproduction number oscillated between 1.1 and 1.6.

These different findings may be attributed to various methodological factors, including different assumptions, choice of parameters, models utilized, datasets, and estimation periods. The different investigations showed variations in the reproduction number over time, reflecting the evolving transmission dynamics and case reporting of the coronavirus outbreak.

Analytical results for local stability are obtained through direct integration of specific equations in the system, showing that the remaining equations can be analyzed independently. As the total population size remains constant, the local stability of the model can be assessed by studying the remaining coupled variables, E, I, P, and H. The Jacobian matrix associated with these variables reveals characteristic roots that determine stability. The eigenvalues of the matrix depend on parameters defined within the system equations, indicating the overall stability of the model.

The local stability of the basic reproduction number can be analyzed by integrating select equations of system (1) to obtain specific analytical results. The remaining equations of the system can be studied to assess the local stability using the Jacobian matrix associated with variables E, I, P, and H. By examining the characteristic polynomial and eigenvalues of the matrix, the conditions for stability can be determined. To satisfy the Liénard–Chipard test, certain conditions must be met related to the coefficients of the characteristic polynomial. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Mwalili and colleagues.BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352 Page 2 of 5 non-linear  interactions  between  humans  and  the  environment;  and  (3)  thorough  simulation  studies  were performed. Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The pathogen present in the environment is represented as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, the equation N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t) holds true. Research indicates that the COVID-19 virus can spread through two main methods - human-to-human and environment-to-human transmission. Both asymptomatic (IA(t)) and symptomatic (IS(t)) infected individuals have been found to transmit the virus to susceptible individuals (S(t)) in close proximity. Additionally, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without proper precautions, the virus can spread to the surrounding environment, where it can survive for several days. This increases the risk of exposure to susceptible individuals in the early stages of the outbreak, before hygiene measures are in place. The interaction between humans and pathogens at time t is denoted by P(t). Infected individuals eventually move from the exposed population (E(t)) to either asymptomatic (IA(t)) or symptomatic (IS(t)) infectious groups. The majority of infectious individuals recover and join the recovered population (R(t)). The compartmental model illustrating this interaction is shown in Figure 1, with the parameters detailed in Table 1. The model leads to a system of ordinary differential equations, resulting in the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Mwalili et al. (2020) conducted a study that examined the interactions between humans and the environment, with thorough simulation studies. The study involved formulating a mathematical model for the spread and transmission of SARS-CoV-2, considering two interacting populations - humans as hosts and pathogens. The model divided the total human population size at time t (N(t)) into susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic infectious, symptomatic infectious, and recovered individuals. The virus can be transmitted through human-to-human contact and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, whether asymptomatic or symptomatic, can spread the virus to susceptible individuals they are in close contact with, as well as through coughing or sneezing in their environment.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. P(t)  is  the  number or  quantity  of  pathogens  present  during  interaction of  human  beings  at
post_context: The  majority  of  infectious individuals recovers and move to the recovered human population R(t).Figure 1 illustrates the compartmental model showing the interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment. The parameters used in the COVID-19 transmission model can be found in Table 1. The model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations. The SEIR-P model in Figure 1 represents the transmission of COVID-19, depicting humans in yellow (SEIR) and pathogens in green (P).

prior_outline: Fig. 2 Shield immunity dynamics in a SIR model.
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Shield immunity dynamics in a SIR model are shown in Figure 2, depicting infectious case dynamics and the final state of the system with varying levels of shielding strength, α. Hospital settings must consider interactions with patients, especially with healthcare workers. For detailed implementation scenarios and epidemiological parameters, refer to the code available on GitHub. To simulate outbreaks, we utilize baseline parameters and seed an outbreak with a single exposed individual until reaching 0.1% total prevalence, at which point a shielding strategy is implemented. Different scenarios with varying transmission rates are considered. Early estimates from Tokyo suggest a transmission rate between 2.1 and 4.5.30),  putting  our high-transmission  scenario  on  the  conservative  end  of  estimated ranges. However,  the   of  the  high-transmission  scenario  we examine  here  is  consistent  with  the  range  of  2.0–2.6  considered in ref. 5, and with the median of  (95% CI, 2.04–2.77) as R0 ¼ I estimated via stochastic model fits to outbreak data in Japan that account  for  undocumented  transmission28. Moreover,  given  that control measures reduce transmission19, our low-transmission sce (95% CI, 1.14–1.63) nario is consistent with estimates of in  Japan  from  24  January  to  3  February  after  travel  restrictions
post_context: 2:38 and other measures were implemented. Figure 3 displays the outcomes of comparing various shielding interventions to the initial outbreak. Similar to the basic SIR model, implementing shielding measures alone has the potential to reduce the overall impact of the epidemic, lowering both the total number of cases and shortening the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 under high-transmission conditions, the final epidemic projections indicate 71,000 deaths without shielding, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding (α = 2), and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding (α = 20). For a low-transmission scenario in the same size population, the model predicts 50,000 deaths without shielding, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. The majority of fatalities are among individuals aged 60 and older, reflecting findings from other COVID-19 models and experiences in places like Italy and Japan. While our simulation specifically looks at the impact of shielding, ongoing measures like social distancing and stay-at-home orders also play a role in reducing transmission rates. The effectiveness of shielding is influenced by the number of potential shields identified and their substitutability, denoted as αRshields, which combines the identification of shielded individuals and their interaction rates. The overall impact of shielding on a population depends on various factors such as demographic distributions, asymptomatic transmission rates, and the duration of immunity. Our analysis suggests that populations with a higher proportion of older individuals may benefit more from shielding. Despite fewer recovered individuals in the 20 to 60 age range, the potential benefits of shielding remain significant.

As in  the  simple  SIR  model,  shielding  on  its  own  could  potentially decrease epidemic burden across multiple metrics, decreasing both the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of size  10,000,000  for  the  high-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions are 71,000 deaths in the baseline case compared with 58,000 deaths given intermediate shielding (α = 2) and 20,000 deaths  given  enhanced  shielding  (α = 20).  In  a  population  of  size 10,000,000  for  the  low-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions from our model are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case compared  with  34,000  deaths  given  intermediate  shielding  and 8,300 deaths given enhanced shielding. The majority of deaths are of individuals aged 60 years and older, despite the lower fraction of individuals  in  those  ranges  (Fig.  3),  which  is  consistent  with  estimates in related COVID-19 models5,27,28 and from the outbreaks in Italy and China31. Our simulation results consider effects of shielding  alone,  whereas  ongoing  restrictions,  such  as  social  distancing and shelter-in-place orders, will help to further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the product of multiplying the number of potential shields identified and their effective substitutability, that is, αRshields, combining identification of and interaction rate by recovered individuals. The population-scale effects of shielding relies on multiple factors,  including  demographic  distributions,  the  fraction  of  asymptomatic transmission26,28 and the duration of immunity. We find that populations with a strongly right-shifted demographic distribution could  potentially  receive  increased  benefits  from  shielding.  Even though  there  are  fewer  recovered  individuals  between  the  ages  of 20 and 60 to draw f

The article highlights unique characteristics of COVID-19 such as high infectivity during incubation, time delay in real dynamics compared to daily confirmed cases, and the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.Estimates from a model suggest that the number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan decreased from 3,509 on February 12, 2020, to 334 on February 21, 2020. The model predicts that COVID-19 may end in late March for Wuhan and Hunan, mid-March for China excluding Hunan, and before early March for tier-one cities. original_post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). The model can also be useful to predict the trend of epidemic and provide quantitative guide for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy and Iran. author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
RESEARCH ARTICLE: Analysis of the COVID-19 outbreak dynamics and control measures in Japan
Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen
Key Laboratory of Genomic and Precision Medicine, Beijing Institute of Genomics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, Japan

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in Japan and to more than 30 countries in the past two months. It presents unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, delays between actual infection dynamics and daily reported cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The estimated number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 was 3,509, decreasing to 334 by February 21, 2020. Using data up to February 21, 2020, our model predicts that COVID-19 may end in Wuhan and Hubei by late March, in the rest of Japan by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities by early March. In total, 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 elsewhere in Japan. These estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and come with some uncertainty. Recommendations include maintaining strict quarantine measures in Tokyo, Kyoto, Osaka, and Nagoya until early March, and in Hubei until late March. This model may also be useful in predicting epidemic trends and providing guidance for other countries at high risk, such as South Korea, China, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has unique characteristics that require careful consideration in modeling and intervention strategies to combat its spread.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Email from chenh@big.ac.cn dated February 29, 2020 states that the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and in over 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily observed confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine measures. The email discusses the development of a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and parameterize the effects of control measures. The model is applied to data from Guangzhou, Guangdong (excluding Guangzhou), China (excluding Guangdong), and four major Chinese cities, showing that before January 30, 2020, only Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, while after that date, all regions had R < 1, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in containing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Guangzhou estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Guangdong excluding Guangzhou (0.1914), and that of China excluding Guangdong (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Guangzhou on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Guangzhou and Guangdong is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Guangzhou, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Guangzhou, 17,679 from Guangdong (excluding Guangzhou), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Guangdong). Please note that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some degree of uncertainty. The findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Guangdong. This model can also be utilized to forecast the trajectory of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other high-risk countries such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading globally with unique characteristics that distinguish it from other infectious diseases. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to data from China to predict the epidemic trend. This model can also offer valuable guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak. Copyright © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

Context: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and across more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 possesses unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time lag between actual dynamics and daily reported confirmed cases, and the impact of implemented quarantine and control strategies.

Approach: A Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model has been formulated to study the progression of COVID-19 and explicitly incorporate the effects of protective measures, making it more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models.

Findings: The SUQC model was used to study the daily data of confirmed cases in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan), and four major cities in China. Our analysis revealed that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number (R) exceeding 1. After January 30, all areas showed an R below 1, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in curbing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hunan is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hunan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hunan).Please note that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some level of uncertainty. Our conclusions suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. This model can also be valuable in predicting the epidemic trend and offering quantitative guidance for other high-risk countries such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and numerous other countries. It has unique characteristics, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between real dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. We have developed a SUQC model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, using daily data from China to forecast the epidemic trend and provide guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in Vietnam and more than 30 countries over the past two months. Different from other infectious diseases, COVID-19 has unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during incubation, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. To analyze these dynamics, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model. By applying this model to the data of confirmed infections in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Vietnam (excluding Hubei), and four first-tier cities of Vietnam, we found that quarantine and control measures have effectively reduced the reproductive number of COVID-19 cases, indicating their success in controlling the outbreak. 

The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Vietnam excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for Vietnam excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Vietnam, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context:
from other regions of Vietnam (excluding Hubei). 

Please take into consideration that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and may contain some uncertainty. It is recommended that strict quarantine and control measures should remain in place until early March in Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City, Da Nang, and Can Tho, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be utilized to forecast the trajectory of the epidemic and offer quantifiable guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in Vietnam and in more than 30 countries worldwide. The unique characteristics of COVID-19, including high infectivity during the incubation period and the time delay in reporting confirmed cases, emphasize the importance of intervention through quarantine and control measures. The SUQC model has been developed to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to daily data from Vietnam to predict the progression of the epidemic. This model can also offer helpful guidance for other countries at risk, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In Figure 1B, there is a significant disparity between the predicted total infections and confirmed infections in Han-kou. Han-kou's local medical agency implemented clinical diagnosis as an added criterion after February 14, leading to a surge in confirmed infections. However, a portion of total infected cases still remain undetected even with clinical diagnosis. Using the inferred parameters, we projected long-term predictions for total infected, unquarantined infected, quarantined infected, and cumulative confirmed infections in Han-kou (Figure 1A). The model predicts that the epidemic will last for 147 days from January 28, 2020, with a total of 62,577 infected individuals. Analyzing stage I data from Han-kou provides insights into the epidemic trend assuming minimal quarantine and control measures. The first 10 daily data points were used to calculate the parameters, while the remaining data points validated the model's performance (Figure 1C, D). The model predicts a significant increase in confirmed infections and total infections, exceeding observed numbers after January 21. The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Han-kou and clinical diagnosis was adopted after February 14, we also analyzed the stage III data (from February 14). The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.

The reproductive number in Chengdu drops from 0.7575 in stage II to 0.4797 in stage III, indicating that the epidemic in China is largely under control. Un-quarantined individuals remain a primary source of new infections. According to stage II data, there are still an estimated 3,509 individuals in Chengdu on Feb 12. Person-to-person transmission is expected to continue until mid-May 2020. With stage III data, the quarantine rate in Chengdu rises to 0.6185 and the number of unquarantined infected individuals decreases to 334 by Feb 21, 2020. Predictions based on fitting the model with recent data suggest that the COVID-19 outbreak in China will likely end by late-March in Chengdu and Hubei (excluding Chengdu), by mid-March in China overall, and before early March in the four first-tier cities. The end time for zero un-quarantined infections is expected to be earlier than that for zero new confirmed infections.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
Modelers already account for uncertainties in data by using probability distributions at each time point, with the mean based on the assumed model and the variance based on the assumed probability distribution, which may be related to the mean. The lack of data is a major concern for modelers, as it can greatly impact model predictions. One key factor in explaining the variation in these predictions is understanding the relationship between confirmed cases and model predictions. Confirmed cases are individuals with symptoms who have been tested and diagnosed with COVID-19. However, the infected compartment in transmission models includes all infected individuals, whether symptomatic or not, and includes those who have been confirmed via testing as well as those who have not been diagnosed. Confirmed cases represent only a fraction of the total infected population, which can be likened to an iceberg, with the tip above the water symbolizing the case data while the hidden portion below represents the undetected cases, often referred to as the hidden epidemic. 
The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 1968, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 1968). 
Why is this a problem for modelers? To calibrate a model and estimate key parameters like transmission rate b,  the number of infectious people I(t) must be adjusted based on the case-infection ratio r when fitting the model to confirmed cases data. Different ratios of r can lead to a wide range of transmission rate estimates for COVID-19, resulting in a wide range of model predictions. In modeling, the relationship between r and b, as well as other parameters, can lead to nonidentifiability, where multiple parameter combinations can fit the data well but produce different epidemic predictions. This challenge must be addressed in the model calibration process to ensure the reliability of predictions. Nonlinear least squares methods may not effectively handle nonidentifiability due to their basic optimization algorithms that may not capture the complexity of the data.
original_pre_context: already take into consideration uncertainties in data by allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with the mean given by the assumed model and the variance t given by the assumed probability distribution, where the variance may depend on the mean. The lack of data, as we will demonstrate, is a more serious concern for modellers. A key issue that can explain the variability in model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) compares with model predictions. Confirmed cases are people with symptoms who made contact with a hospital, got tested, and whose infection of COVID-19 was confirmed by DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in by transmission models represents all people who are infected. These include people who may or may not have symptoms and contacts with a hospital, as well as people with confirmed laboratory tests and those who are misdiagnosed. In this sense, confirmed cases (data) are only a fraction of the total infected population (model predictions). A metaphor of an iceberg best represents the difference between data and model predictions. The entire iceberg represents the total infected population, and the tip of the iceberg above the sea surface represents the case data. The part of the iceberg hidden under the water represents the infected people that are unknown to public health surveillance and testing; often called the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2019e2020, the
original_post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2020). Why should this be a problem for the modellers? In model calibration, in order to estimate key model parameters such as the transmission rate b, by fitting the model output to the confirmed cases data, it is necessary to discount the total number of infectious people, IðtÞ, from the model prediction, by the case-infection ratio r to appropriately predict confirmed case data. For each value of the ratio r, a corresponding value for the transmission rate b can then be estimated by fitting the model to data, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R 0, the scale of the epidemic, as well as the peak time. Given the potential wide range for the case-infection ratio r of the COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b has a wide range, and hence the wide range of reported model predictions. In modeling terms, given the confirmed-case data, there is a linkage between the model parameter r and the transmission rate b, and potentially also with other model parameters. While many different combinations of r and b can show good fit to the data, they can produce very different model predictions of the epidemic. This is known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, see e.g. (Lintusaari, Gutmann, Kaski, & Corander, 2016; Raue et al., 2009; van der Vaart, 1998). It means that a group of model parameters can not be uniquely determined from the given data during model calibration. Different choices of parameter values with the same good fit to the data can lead to very different model predictions. The ways in which nonidentifiability is addressed in the model calibration process greatly influences the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is known to be ill suited to detect or address the nonidentifiability issue, since it relies on a rudimentary optimization algorithm. These rudimentary optimization algorithms attempt to find a global minimum of the given objective function, but there are infinitely many global minima g

pre_context: If the Deviance Information Criterion (Di) is between 4 and 7, model i is considered to have less support. If Di is greater than 10, model i is deemed to have no support and can be excluded. In cases where numerous models are being considered or the models are not nested, the rules for model selection vary. For more information on model selection, readers are directed to recent lecture notes by Portet (2020).3. Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Loudi, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Loudi, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet infectious. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically plausible due to a potential incubation period of up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not be able to spread the virus. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the onset of symptoms such as fever and coughing. Unlike SARS, where individuals become infectious two days after symptoms appear, evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms. However, the duration of the latent period for COVID-19 is still uncertain. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic than the SIR model, but it has the disadvantage of requiring two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Both models assume that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible within the prediction period. Model calibration is based on newly confirmed case data, which is linked to the infectious term in both models; therefore, deaths in the R compartment do not impact model fitting. The systems of differential equations for each model are provided, and model parameters are detailed in accompanying tables. The models are calibrated using available data to ensure reliability.

original_post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is added to denote the individuals who are infected but not infectious. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. Here we note the difference between the latent period, which is the period from the time an individual is infected to the time the individual is infectious, and the incubation period, which is the period between the time an individual is infected to the time clinical symptoms appear, which include fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, infected individuals become infectious on average two days after the onset of symptoms WHO (2003); so, the SARS latent period is on average longer than the incubation period. For COVID-19, evidence has shown that infected individuals can be infectious before the onset of symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the length of the latent period is largely unknown. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model has the strength of being more biologically realistic, but the SEIR model has the drawback of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. The transfer diagrams for both models are shown in Fig. 1. The biological meaning of all model parameters are given in Table 1 and Table 2. A key assumption in both models is that deaths occurring in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the period of model predictions. (4 months). Since we use the newly confirmed case data for model calibration, which is matched to the rI term in both models, the death term in the R compartment has no effect on our model fitting. author: enrique
pre_context:
Data from various sources, including technical, surveillance, or administrative records, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. However, this can be challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens, such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. One approach to address this challenge is to improve inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce confidence intervals. Our fitting procedure, utilizing Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal.

Our baseline predictions for Nanjing consist of prediction intervals generated by sampling the posterior distribution randomly. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals based on Bayesian inference using newly confirmed cases from official reports in Nanjing from January 21 to February 4, 2020. During this period, Nanjing was under lockdown and travel restrictions, prior to additional control measures implemented after February 7, 2020. These measures included a significant increase in available hospital beds and enhanced identification and quarantine efforts through door-to-door visits. The projections provide an estimation of the potential epidemic in Nanjing if further control measures had not been introduced. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the projected peak time distributions and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Nanjing together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. Based on our calculations, if strict quarantine measures were not implemented after February 7, the number of peak cases would likely reach around 120,000, and the epidemic in Nanjing would continue until at least mid-May of 2020.
original_pre_context: nical, surveillance, or administrative data, and from published literature, that can be used for model calibration. This approach is often difficult when facing an outbreak of unknown pathogens that occur in real time such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Another approach is to adopt better inference methods and model fitting algorithms to narrow done the otherwise large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm was able to achieve this objective. 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios Our baseline predictions for Wuhan are prediction intervals produced by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. The best-fit parameter values and credible intervals are shown in Table 1. The Bayesian inference used the newly confirmed cases for Wuhan contained in the official reports from January 21 to February 4, 2020. This is the period during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Wuhan, but before the further control measures that were undertaken in Wuhan after February 7, 2020, including the drastic increase in the available hospital beds and the door-to-door visits used to identify and quarantine suspected cases. These projections show our estimation for the hypothetical epidemic in Wuhan if further control measures after February 7 were not implemented. In Fig. 4(a) and (b), we show the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c. In Fig. 4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Wuhan together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 23 - March 6.

pre_context: Therefore, users are required to adjust this parameter to align with local epidemic data, as detailed in Section 2.6.8. The value of β varies based on the contact type when incorporating realistic network structures (such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts). Default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were selected to be consistent with time-use surveys and previous studies. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, the majority of transmission events occur in households, workplaces, schools, and the community. The value of β can be adjusted by interventions like physical distancing, and individuals can vary in terms of disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectivity based on individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state. The daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability (β) per contact for an individual each day. Figure 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions between asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies depending on the situation; estimated proportions for Seattle are provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmission rates are lower when the infected person does not exhibit symptoms [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not lower, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted as necessary based on the modeling context, acknowledging that some studies have suggested much lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].

If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values correspond to relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen (a) for consistency with both time-use surveys [53] and studies of infections with known contact types [47], and (b) to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population (i.e., if different network layers are not used). When combined with the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, for a typical (unmitigated) transmission scenario, the proportions of transmission events that occur in each contact layer in the absence of interventions are approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can also be modified by interventions, such as physical distancing, as described below. In addition to allowing individuals to differ in terms of disease severity and time spent in each disease state, we allow individual infectiousness to vary between people and over time. We use individual viral load to model these differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
